children.subject: Doesn't directly address what you want, but Hamiltonians/the variational principle come out of physics that's covered in Physics 105 and in this Feynman lecture!

history.content:
We did touch a bit of control theory in EE 127 towards the end with LQR but it wasn't super in depth, only 1-2 lectures. I'm sure that with the background EE127 gives you, it would probably be easier to pick up by reading the relevant literature.

From looking at the syllabi, I think courses like EE C128 (Feedback Control Systems), EE106A/B (Robotics) are probably better although I haven't taken them yet (I plan to take them next year), someone who has taken them can probably comment. 

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Math 185 covers tiny maximum principle. I do not recommend taking Math 185 just for maximum principle.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
All those topics are covered in EE 223. But it was just offered this past semester, so it will take a while until it is offered again.
Also, dynamic optimization is most commonly referred to as dynamic programming,
and the Hamiltonian is a concept that shows up in the maximum principle which is part of the optimal control theory.

We did touch a bit of control theory in EE 127 towards the end with LQR but it wasn't super in depth, only 1-2 lectures. I'm sure that with the background EE127 gives you, it would probably be easier to pick up by reading the relevant literature.

From looking at the syllabi, I think courses like EE C128 (Feedback Control Systems), EE106A/B (Robotics) are probably better although I haven't taken them yet (I plan to take them next year), someone who has taken them can probably comment. 

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Math 185 covers tiny maximum principle. I do not recommend taking Math 185 just for maximum principle.

We did touch a bit of control theory in EE 127 towards the end with LQR but it wasn't super in depth, only 1-2 lectures. I'm sure that with the background EE127 gives you, it would probably be easier to pick up by reading the relevant literature.

From looking at the syllabi, I think courses like EE C128 (Feedback Control Systems), EE106A/B (Robotics) are probably better although I haven't taken them yet (I plan to take them next year), someone who has taken them can probably comment.

We did touch a bit of control theory in EE 127 towards the end with LQR but it wasn't super in depth, only 1-2 lectures. I'm sure that with the background EE127 gives you, it would probably be easier to pick up by reading the relevant literature.

From looking at the syllabi, I think courses like EE C128 (Feedback Control Systems), EE106A/B (Robotics) are probably better although I haven't taken them yet (I plan to take them next year), someone who has taken them can probably comment.

children.subject: You may also want to consider Math 170. See @8891 for more info.

history.content:
Hello! 


I am not sure if this is the right place to ask this but I am interested in pursuing grad school abroad, and the prerequisite knowledge includes dynamic optimization, comprising: 

a. Optimal Control

b. Hamiltonian

c. The Maximum Principle

Can anyone advise if this was covered in EE127? Or if anyone has taken/knows a Math/EE class which deals with these topics/ dynamic optimization, I would really appreciate any advice. Thank you!
history.subject: Where to learn dynamic optimization?
